description.en:
The course will in each different year examine a particular work in moral philosophy that is
especially significant in the history of moral philosophy and that continues to be relevant
for contemporary debates, whether in normative ethics, metaethics, applied ethics, etc.
description.et: Kursuse käigus vaadeldakse igal aastal üht moraalifilosoofia ajaloos eriliselt tähenduslikku teksti, mis püsib olulisena ka tänapäeva normatiivse eetika, metaeetika ja rakenduseetika alastes debattides.

objectives.en:
Objectives:
1. To offer a systematic introduction to a significant text in moral
philosophy.
2. To show the importance of the text both in the
author's context and for contemporary debates in ethics.
3. To reconstruct and assess the plausibility of the views and
arguments presented in the text.
objectives.et:
Kursuse eesmärkideks on:
* tutvustada tudengitele süstemaatiliselt üht moraalifilosoofia olulist teksti,
* näidata selle teksti tähtsust nii autori vaadete kui tänapäeva moraalifilosoofiliste debattide kontekstis,
* rekonstrueerida tekstis esitatud argumendid ja seisukohad ning hinnata nende veenvust.

learning_outcomes.en:
On successful completion of the course the student:
1. has a solid knowledge of a given text/author's
moral philosophy and of what makes it distinctive,
2. is able to critically assess the arguments for and against the
views presented in the text,
3. is able to read and understand a noncontemporary
text and relate it to contemporary
philosophical concerns,
4. is able to understand and analyze scholarly articles,
5. is able to engage with the issues both in spoken and written form.
learning_outcomes.et:
Kursuse edukalt läbinud üliõpilane:
* omab head ülevaadet käsitletud moraalifilosoofia põhitekstist ning teab, mis on selle teksti iseloomulikud jooned,
* oskab kriitiliselt hinnata argumente tekstis esitatud väidete poolt ja vastu,
* suudab lugeda ja mõista ajaloolist filosoofilist teksti ning suhestada seda tänapäevaste filosoofiliste küsimustega,
* suudab teadusartiklitest aru saada ja neid analüüsida,
* on võimeline avaldama käsitletud teemadel arvamust nii suuliselt kui kirjalikult.

notes.et:
Autumn 2017: J. S. Mill, Utilitarianism.

This course examines John Stuart Mill's utilitarianism, through a close reading of his essay Utilitarianism (1861). The book has five chapters: 1. General Remarks; 2. What Utilitarianism Is; 3. Of the Ultimate Sanction of the Principle of Utility; 4. Of What Sort of Proof the Principle of Utility is Susceptible; and 5. On the Connection Between Justice and Utility. In the study materials I will indicate secondary literature that will help us in our interpretation and serve as basis for the written essay.

independent_work.et:
Preparing for seminars (or compensate by homework);
doing the homework by the assigned deadlines.

description.et:
1. COLLOQUIUM AND REPORT
Attendance and active participation to seminars. Classes will be devoted to a brief introduction to the text to be read for the seminar. Most of the time will be devoted for seminars. Active participation to seminars means coming to class ready to both ask and answer questions about the text given for that seminar, either individually or as part of a small group. Having read the text is a pre-condition for seminar discussion. Having understood it fully or even partly is not. Coming to class knowing what you didn't understand is a great start.
Also, each student will be required to draw a brief report of ONE seminar discussion in their group, to be then read out during the next class (i.e. on Wednesdays) and posted on Moodle.

2. HOMEWORK
Roughly every second week, specific questions set by the lecturer are to be answered within a given amount of words. The point of the homework is both to check ongoing understanding and offer possibilities of own critical contribution. The questions will be found in moodle.

3. ESSAY
The point of the essay is to reconstruct and possibly critically comment on a scholarly article on the given author/work. The essay's length should be between 1500 and 3000 words.

grade_preconditions.et: Students must attend and participate in all seminars (or compensate by homework), and do the homework by the assigned deadlines.

grade_evaluation.et:
To obtain the final grade, the following is required
33% based on seminar discussion and report.
33% based on homework.
34% based on essay.

debt_elimination.et: In the case of unsubmitted homework or missed seminars, the lecturer will arrange compensatory activities.

resources.mandatory_materials:
* John Stuart Mill, Utilitarianism, R. Crisp (ed. and introduction), Oxford University Press, 1998. 
The book is also contained in many collections of Mill's works. The library has some of them. It is also easily found online, for example: https://www.utilitarianism.com/mill1.htm. 
It is strongly recommended that you bring your own copy (book or photocopies or online document) to class, because we will want to read together precise passages.
* Secondary literature on Mill that is available from university library is indicated in the study materials.
All study materials will be in any case uploaded in the Moodle page of the course.
